description: From Middle English steward, stiward, from Old English stīweard, stiġweard (“steward, housekeeper, one who has the superintendence of household affairs, guardian”), from stiġ (“a wooden enclosure; house, hall”) + weard (“ward, guard, guardian, keeper”), equivalent to sty +‎ ward. Compare Icelandic stívarður (“steward”). More at sty, ward.

definitionGroups.group: A person who manages the property or affairs for another entity

entries.meaning: (historical) A chief administrator of a medieval manor.
(nautical) A ship's officer who is in charge of making dining arrangements and provisions.
A union member who is selected as a representative for fellow workers in negotiating terms with management.
A person who has charge of buildings, grounds, and/or animals.
Someone responsible for organizing an event
A fiscal agent of certain bodies.
examples: a steward in a Methodist church

entries.meaning: A junior assistant in a Masonic lodge.
(higher education) An officer who provides food for the students and superintends the kitchen; also, an officer who attends to the accounts of the students.
(Scotland) A magistrate appointed by the crown to exercise jurisdiction over royal lands.
(information technology) Somebody who is responsible for managing a set of projects, products or technologies and how they affect the IT organization to which they belong.
(motor racing) Person responsible for the arbitration of incidents at a motor racing event and whether or not fines/penalties should be issued for such incidents.

verbs.description: steward (third-person singular simple present stewards, present participle stewarding, simple past and past participle stewarded)

entries.meaning: To act as the steward or caretaker of (something)
